title: Pioneer Violet
creator: Gerald D. Carr
description: Wild cousins of the pansy, yellow wood violets add a charming element to shady understory groundcover in the spring. As its name suggests, it does well in rich, moist woodland soils with full to partial shade. Unlike other native violets that grow in low basal rosettes, yellow wood violets' erect stems grow to 1 ft tall with flowers blooming at shoot tips.  The distinctive asymmetrical flowers are bright yellow with maroon veins and look lovely against heart-shaped leaves.
image_alt_text: A photo of a green plant with rounded leaves and bright yellow flowers.
subject: Plant; Edible Plants; Native Plants; Photograph (Visual Works)
source: Viola glabella Nutt. - OregonFlora
citation: Carr, Gerald D. "Viola Glabella." OregonFlora, 18 Apr. 2006, oregonflora.org/taxa/index.php?taxon=9126. Accessed 14 Feb. 2024.
rights: IN COPYRIGHT - EDUCATIONAL USE PERMITTED

title: Queen Anne's Lace
creator: Warren E. Favor
description: A part of the carrot & parsley family (Daucus carota). Imported from Europe by the colonists. This flower has spread rapidly because even the shortest tongued insect can enjoy the nectar it secretes, thus fertilizing it. Then the flower folds inwards (like a newt). The cultivated carrot was never derived from this plant; although fiction tries to give credit to the Dutch for accomplishing it. When the cultivated carrot reverts to its ancestral type it is quite different.
image_alt_text: A photo of a plant from on top with numerous white tiny flowers in clusters.
subject: Plant; Edible Plants; Native Plants; Medicinal Plants; Photograph (Visual Works)
source: Queen Anne's lace - Digital Public Library of America
citation: Favor, Waren. "Queen Anne's lace." Digital Public Library of America, 1946-1960, dp.la/item/084006b9c03b890086d9ee86c6f73821?q=Queen+Anne%27s+Lace. Accessed 14 Feb. 2024.
rights: COPYRIGHT NOT EVALUATED

title: Bitter Cherry
creator: Bruce N. Newhouse
description: Bitter cherry is an attractive small tree or shrub with shiny reddish to silvery gray bark and leaves that turn yellow in the fall. Pretty white flowers bloom in clusters and mature into a profusion of bright red cherry-like fruits that are devoured by birds. It does well in full to partial sun and is well-suited to the woodland garden or hedgerow where it can form lovely flowering thickets if suckers are left unchecked.
image_alt_text: A photo of a fruit tree that grows many tiny flowers that sprout into cherries.
subject: Plant; Poisonous Plants; Medicinal Plants; Photograph (Visual Works)
source: Prunus emarginata (Douglas ex Hook.) Walp. - OregonFlora
citation: Newhouse, Bruce N. "Prunus Emarginata." OregonFlora, oregonflora.org/taxa/index.php?taxon=7679. Accessed 14 Feb. 2024.

title: Wild Currant
creator: Cleveland Rockwell
description: The Wild Currant flower, also known as Ribes, typically features clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that come in shades of pink, red, white, or yellow. The flowers have a delicate and dainty appearance, often blooming in spring and attracting pollinators with their sweet fragrance. Additionally, the plant's foliage is characterized by lobed leaves that complement the colorful and charming flowers.
image_alt_text: Color botanical illustration of wild currant with foliage and two clusters of small pink blooms. There are four large, dark green, ivy-shaped leaves connected to a thin brown stem
subject: Plant; Flowers; Botanical Illustration; Drawings (Visual Works); Native Plants
source: Cleveland Rockwell Papers - OHS Digital Collection

title: Chocolate Lily
creator: Gerald D. Carr
description: The Chocolate Lily flower, also known as Fritillaria biflora, is characterized by its deep brown to purplish petals that resemble the color of chocolate. It typically has a bell-shaped bloom with dark markings on the petals, giving it a rich and velvety appearance.
image_alt_text: A unique flower with dark purple, almost brownish petals and prominent yellow pollen-covered anthers. There is also an unopened bud on the plant. The background is dark, and there are water droplets on the plant, suggesting a wetland or marshy environment.
subject: Plant; Bulbous Plants; Edible Plants; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works)
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: “Fritillaria affinis,” Gerald D. Carr. 05 Aug 2007, OregonFlora Field Photo Collection, https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=1543252

title: English Sundew
creator: Gerald D. Carr
description: The English Sundew, a carnivorous plant, is known for its small, round leaves covered in sticky red tentacles that attract and trap insects. These tentacles resemble drops of dew, giving the plant its name. The plant's unique feature is its ability to digest the insects it captures to obtain nutrients in environments with poor soil conditions.
image_alt_text: A close-up of a sundew plant, known for its sticky, glandular tentacles that trap and digest insects. The leaves have glistening droplets and range in color from green to reddish. The background is dark, making the plant stand out.
subject: Plant; Carnivorous Plants; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works)
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: “Drosera anglica,” Gerald D. Carr. 18 Aug 2007, OregonFlora Field Photo Collection, https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=1578794
rights: In Copyright

title: Fawn-Lily
creator: Carl Burt
description: The Fawn Lily flower, also known as Erythronium, typically has delicate, nodding blooms with petals that resemble the shape of a fawn's ear. The petals are usually white or pink with yellow or golden centers, and the plant often grows in woodland areas, adding a touch of elegance to its surroundings.
image_alt_text: A close-up cluster of flowers with six light purple petals and a yellow-green center. The petals have subtle white streaks and fade to a pale, almost purple color near the edges. The flower has a delicate and vibrant appearance, and the background is dark, which makes the flowers stand out.
subject: Plant; Bulbous Plants; Edible Plants; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works)
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: “Erythronium hendersonii,” Cal Burt. OregonFlora Field Photo Collection, https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=1539883
rights: In Copyright

title: Foxglove
creator: Gerald D. Carr
description: The Foxglove flower, also known as Digitalis, is recognized for its tall spikes of tubular flowers that come in shades of pink, purple, white, or yellow. The petals have a speckled or spotted pattern inside and a bell-like shape, creating a striking and elegant appearance. Additionally, the plant's leaves are often large, lance-shaped, and arranged in a rosette at the base.
image_alt_text: The picture is of a bee on a pink and purple flower. The bee is fuzzy and yellow with black stripes, and it looks like it's collecting nectar or pollen from the flower. The flower has a spotted pattern inside and is hanging downward. The background is blue, and the bee and flower are in focus, while the background is blurry.
subject: Plant; Poisonous Plants; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works); Invasive Plants; Common Plants
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: “Digitalis purpurea,” Gerald D. Carr. 19 Aug 2006, OregonFlora Field Photo Collection, https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=1550301
rights: In Copyright

title: Love in a Mist
creator: Gerald D. Carr
description: Love-in-a-Mist flowers, also known as Nigella, typically have feathery bracts and intricate flower structures. They often feature a central core of stamens or pistils surrounded by delicate, papery petals in shades of blue, white, or pink. Additionally, they may have spiky green bracts that radiate outwards, giving the flower a unique and striking appearance.
image_alt_text: A close-up of a unique flower with light blue petals and long, thin, green spiky appendages. The central part of the flower is a cluster of immature stamens or pistils that are greenish in color. The colors are vibrant, and the background is soft and indistinct.
subject: Plant; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works); Native Plants; Edible Plants; Medicinal Plants
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: “Nigella damascena,” Gerald D. Carr. 17 Jun 2017, OregonFlora Field Photo Collection, https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=2994618
rights: In Copyright

title: Norton's St. John's wort
creator: Bruce N. Newhouse
description: The St. John's Wort flower, scientifically known as Hypericum perforatum, typically features bright yellow, star-shaped flowers with numerous stamens in the center. The petals are arranged in a symmetrical pattern, giving the flower a vibrant and cheerful appearance. Additionally, the plant is known for its use in herbal medicine due to the medicinal properties of its flowers and leaves.
image_alt_text: The picture shows bright yellow flowers, likely from the Hypericum genus, with long, slender, yellow stamens and delicate petals. The leaves are rich green, and the background suggests the plant is in a garden or wild area with ample sunlight.
subject: Plant; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works); Native Plants; Edible Plants
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: “Hypericum scouleri,” Bruce N. Newhouse. 01 Aug 2010, OregonFlora Field Photo Collection,https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=1555224
rights: In Copyright

title: Phantom Orchid
creator: Gerald D. Carr
description: The Phantom Orchid, or Cephalanthera austiniae, is a rare and elusive orchid known for its ghostly appearance. It has white, waxy flowers with intricate patterns that resemble ethereal spirits, often growing in shady, forested areas. The plant lacks chlorophyll and relies on a symbiotic relationship with fungi for nutrients, adding to its mysterious and captivating nature.
image_alt_text: A cluster of white orchid flowers with a velvety texture and a yellow center. The flowers are arranged in a dense, vertical spike.
subject: Plant; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works); Edible Plants; Endangered Plants; Rare Plants; Native Plants
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: “Cephalanthera austiniae,” Gerald D. Carr. 10 Jul 2008, OregonFlora Field Photo Collection, https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=1549877
rights: In Copyright

title: Scotchbroom
creator: Paul Slichter
description: The Scotch Broom flower, or Cytisus scoparius, is characterized by bright yellow, pea-like flowers that bloom abundantly on woody stems. The flowers form dense clusters along the branches, creating a vibrant display of color. Additionally, the plant's foliage consists of small, needle-like leaves that complement the striking yellow blossoms.
image_alt_text: A bushy shrub with lots of small, bright yellow flowers. The flowers cover the shrub, and there are green leaves and stems. The background looks like a sandy or grassy area. The shrub is the main focus of the picture.
subject: Plant; Shrubs; Invasive Plants; Flowers; Photograph (Visual Works); Edible Plants; Common Plants
source: OregonFlora Field Photo Collection
citation: Cytisus scoparius, Paul Slichter, 21 May 2009, OregonFlora Field Photo Collection, https://oregonflora.org/collections/individual/index.php?occid=1566571
